text:
NETGEAR has been in
business for more than 25 years
and having two main business units,
one on the consumer side

and another on the small
and the medium business side.

And we have been an AWS
customer for almost a decade now.

Within my group, I
have four main pillars.

Our first pillar
being business applications,

which is responsible for
all our corporate applications.

And then the second
pillar is cybersecurity.
The third pillar is analytics,

where we do everything
being data-driven for the company.
And last but not the least is the pillar

for cloud operations
and the global infrastructure.

When we started this
journey about the migration onto AWS,
so we had options of,

hey, do we want to use
Oracle OCI or we want to use AWS?

So we did that analysis
and it turned out to be that EBS

or Oracle e-Business
Suite is just a piece of it.
There are other peripheral systems
which encompasses the entire ERP suite.
So when we evaluated the whole ecosystem,

we felt that it
better be using a cloud provider

which has services
available for modernizing,

making sure that all
these peripherals ecosystem
work pretty well with our ERP stack
and the analytics on top of it, right?

So since we are a
big data-driven organization,

we want to continue that
data-driven initiative as well.

Taking all those
things into consideration,

we decided to take
our journey towards AWS.

We decided to migrate all
our data center into AWS stack,
including our Oracle e-Business Suite.

The migration readiness
assessment, we started with that.

And that helped us in
knowing in terms of where we are,
and how we want to go there,
and what are the various things
that we need to take advantage of.

Then that led to the
Oracle licensing assessment aspect
of it that came into picture.
Then we did the well-architected review

of terms of how to run
Oracle Suite better onto an AWS stack,

how will the peripheral
systems integrate well with that,

what services or
capabilities we should be leveraging
to make that better.

We started this journey
of migration earlier this year,
and sometime in January,
with the deadline that we need to migrate

all our 160
applications with close to 400 terabytes
of data by end of September.

And we were very
fortunate to be able to achieve that
within eight months.

The team did a
phenomenal job working with AWS,

bringing in the AWS
expertise in every aspect of it,
where we did the well-architected review.

The AWS team worked
hand in hand with NETGEAR team
to make that happen and make it possible.

And with all the things
that AWS has been delivering

or the innovation or
the reinventing aspect of it
with the various services,

that made NETGEAR
business expand pretty fast.
There are many benefits that the team

or the company
organization achieved out of this.

The first being is the
synergy of having everything
running into a platform.
The second big benefit is cost.
So being able to leverage AWS services,
the platform ecosystem,

and we have been able
to save licensing aspect to it.
Those were, I would say, the key factors
in terms of centralizing everything

and adding it to it
as a security aspect of it.

Running an
ecosystem into a cloud platform,
which has embedded security into it,
made it easier for NETGEAR to be able
to launch those more securely.

Cost, security,
disaster recovery, high availability,

those were the key
benefits that NETGEAR was able
to get benefit out of this migration.
As NETGEAR products,

we also provide
cybersecurity services for our home.

We also provide
parental control services.
And on top of that,
we also have a support offering as well.

All the cybersecurity
solutions is also using AWS
as a backbone.
And so taking those aspects to it

and using the AWS platform
to help improve those services,

that brings value to
the customer experience as well.

So now any innovation,
anything that we would like to do,
it made it simpler and easier for us.
